metadata.title: Anterior Cruciate Ligament Tear  Pediatric
description: The vast majority of pediatric ACL injuries occur in adolescents.(1,2)In this article, the WHO definition of adolescent applies (i.e., children11 to 18 years of age)

The incidence of ACL reconstruction in the pediatric population is increasing.(3)Authors of an epidemiological study in the United States found that ACL reconstructionsaccounted for3.2%of 470,126 patients age 18 years or younger who underwent any orthopedic surgeryfrom 2004 to 2014. During that 10-year  period, there was a 2.8-fold  increase in ACL reconstructions relative to total pediatric orthopedic surgeries(51)

Classifications of ACL injuries in children(4,5) –Avulsion of intercondylar eminence (tibial spine fracture) –Avulsion of femoral or tibial attachment –Avulsion of both femoral and tibial attachment –Midsubstance rupture, a tear within the substance of the ligament other than the bony attachment, which is the focus of this Clinical Review

Classification of ligament sprains(4) –First-degree  sprain: No gross tear or laxity –Second-degree  sprain: Partial tear; this category is not well-defined –Third-degree  sprain: Complete tear with gross laxity and a soft endpoint

Anatomy – The ACL originates from the posterior aspect of the medial surface of the lateral femoral condyle with a broad insertion anterior and lateral to the tibial spine. The ACL consists of 2–3bundles of fibers: anteromedial, posterolateral, and intermediate(5,6) –Anteromedial bundle is tight with flexion –Posterolateral bundle is tight during extension

Function: The ACL prevents anterior translation of the tibia on the femur. It also prevents knee hyperextension, provides resistance to internal rotation of the tibia, and aids in varus/valgus stability at the knee joint.(5,6)The much less commonly injured posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) functions to limit the posterior translation of the tibia and is most often torn in forced knee hyperflexion(4)

presentation signs and symptoms: Acute injury –Effusion -Swelling occurs rapidly, within several hours of the injury(7) -Most ACL and meniscal injuries are accompanied by joint effusion(31) –Pain(6) –Acute instability: Individual is unable to continue with activity/weight bearing on injured lower extremity(6) –Loss of ROM, specifically knee extension(8) –Decreased lower extremity strength –Antalgic gait(8)
Chronic injury (ACL-deficient  knee) –Episodes of pain, swelling, and instability Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: More than 70% of pediatric ACL injuries are caused by noncontact forces, as compared to the trauma-related  PCLinjuries(9)

The mechanism of injury in adolescents differs from that in preadolescents(14)–Adolescents-Noncontact sports injury that involves a sudden deceleration and rotation occurring on a planted or fixed foot(1,4,5)-Quick change of direction-Plant and cut movement-Landing from a jump(9,10)-Hyperextension of the knee(3)-Contact sports injury: Similar elements to noncontact injury; plus knee varus, valgus, hyperextension, or hyperflexion(1)–Preadolescents-Sports are not the primary cause in children younger than 11 years old(1,2,4,9)-Fall or twist that involves knee hyperextension(1)

Incidence: 250,000–300,000  ACL injuries occur annually in young, active individuals in the United States. The rate hasincreased considerably in children over the past 10–20  years(11,39,47)–This rise is thought to be related to higher rates of sports participation, earlier sports specialization, increased intensityof play/sport, year-round  sport training, poor conditioning, participation on multiple teams or in multiple sports in oneseason, and competing at a much younger age(39)
Children who are skeletally immature account for 0.5% to 3.0% of all ACL injuries in the United States(31,39)
Young athletes 15–25  years of age sustain > 50% of all ACL injuries(9)
pathogenesis: Injury patterns of the ACL may vary considerably related to age(31)–Most ACL injuries in the pediatric population result from osteochondral avulsion fractures of the tibial eminence,most often during puberty. However, osteochondral avulsion fractures of the femoral attachment site of the ACL areuncommon(12,31)–Tibial spine/eminence fractures occur from high-energy, slow-loading  injuries(3,4,9)

Findings suggest that midsubstance tears in children are not as uncommon as once believed and are increasingly likely tooccur as a child develops from preadolescence to adolescence(12)–Partial thickness tears tend to occur among adolescents prior to skeletal maturity, whereas complete ACL tears typicallyoccur in adolescents who are skeletally mature(31)–Midsubstance ACL tears result from low-energy,  rapid-loading injuries causing multiplanar forces to the knee(3,4,26)-“Position of no return”: minimal knee and hip flexion and a valgus knee(26)
More than two-thirds  (> 66%) of patients with complete ACL tears have associated menisci and/or articular cartilageinjury(9)

Benefits of early pediatric ACL reconstruction(5)–Authors of a 2018 meta-analysis  (N = 1353 children, mean age 14.2 years, range 6 to 19; 45% female) found severalbenefits in the 26% who were reconstructed early (open physes) compared to the 47% with delayed reconstruction (closedphyses).(52)The results showed significantly decreased risks for-concomitant medial meniscal injury-chondral damage in the medial femoral, lateral femoral, and patellofemoral compartments

Complications after pediatric ACL reconstruction(53)–Authors of a 2019 meta-analysis  (N = 1321 patients) found that over a mean follow-up  of 49.6 months, the most commoncomplications were rerupture requiring revision, growth disturbance requiring corrective surgery, angular deformity, andleg-length  discrepancy

Return to sport after pediatric ACL reconstruction(7,8)–Authors of a 2018 meta-analysis  of 1156 ACL reconstructions in children (mean age 14.3 years, range 6 to 19) and amean follow-up  time of 6.5 years (range 1 to 22) found a high rate of return to sport(54)-The pooled rates of return were 92.0% to any sport participation, 78.6% to pre-injury  level of sport, and 81.0% tocompetitive level of sport-At follow-up,  13% had sustained reinjuries with graft ruptures; 14% had contralateral ACL injuries
risk factors: Sports–Greater incidence of noncontact ACL injuries in sports requiring cutting, pivoting, and rapid deceleration(9)–The participation rate of girls in sports has increased dramatically in North America over the last 3 decades, resulting inan increased number of musculoskeletal injuries, particularly ACL injuries(26)-During pubertyACL injury rates increase sharply in girls, who have higher rates of noncontact ACL injuries than boys insimilar sports(47)–Biomechanical limitations(26,36)-Decreased knee flexion angles (greater knee flexion in landingfrom a jump) have been associated with higher anteriortibial shear forces, increasing the strain on the ACL-Mechanical coupling of knee abduction and internal tibial rotational forces have been associated with increased ACLloading and strain in the ACL–Fatigue-Fatigue alters lower limb biomechanical and neuromuscular factors,placing the individual at greater risk for ACLinjury(36)-Authors of a study involving youth elite soccer players in the United Kingdom concluded that fatigue severelycompromises neuromuscular control of knee stabilizers, increasing risk of fatigue-relatedACL injury(50)-Thirty-six  female youth soccer players ranging in age from 13 to 17 years old participated in the study-Subjects performed pre-fatigue  (baseline) measures and post-fatigue  (follow-up)  measures of electromechanical delay(EMD). EMD was defined as the time from the onset of muscle activity to the onset of force generation via muscleaction. EMD was measured via a Biodex System-3  isokinetic dynamometer (Biodex Corp., Shirley, New York, USA)and a wireless 8-channel  Delsys electromyography (EMG) telemetry system (DelsysMyomonitor III, Delsys Inc.,Boston, Massachusetts, USA)-Knee dynamometry was performed in the prone position with 10–20  degrees passive hip flexion to replicate kneeflexor and extensor length-tension relationships in the late phase or early contact phase of sprinting, landing, andpivoting (to increase ACL loading). ROM was set from 90 degrees knee flexion to 0 degrees-EMG activity of the semitendinosus, biceps femoris, and gastrocnemius muscles was measured-Between measures, the patients participated in soccer-specific  training using the SAFT⁹⁹ protocol, which included20-m  distance shuttle runs, walking, jogging, side stepping, and sprinting for 75–90  minutes-EMD was significantly increased post-activity. Younger participants (13 years old) had significantly longerpost-activity  EMD compared to 15–17-year-old  participants–High-risk  sports-Football, soccer, skiing, hockey (ice and field), basketball, lacrosse, gymnastics, wrestling, and volleyball(7,8,32)-American football players are known to have the greatest relative risk for sustaining knee injuries, followed closely bygirl soccer players(31,48)-Girls who play soccer, basketball, and volleyball have a higher rate of ACL injuries than boys who play football(31)-ACL injury rates for child alpine skiing have been reported to be 3.9 to 9.1 injuries per 1,000 skier days, with the highestrates in children 1 to 10 years of age(32)–Moderate-risk  sports-Baseball, softball, track (nonjumping events), and tennis (doubles)(1)–Low-risk  sports-Swimming, crew, and jogging(7,8)

Sex:–Within the same sport, female athletes have 2 to 8 times greater risk of ACL injury compared to male athletes, but there isno single risk factor that correlates directly with higher ACL injury rates in female athletes. This sex disparity is apparentfrom the onset of puberty and is likely multifactorial. The following variables are associated with increased risk for ACLinjuries in females:(9,10,13,27,38)-Anatomical(10)-Increased Q-angle(9,10)-Increased genuvalgum(9,10)-Increased pelvic tilt(36)-Smaller ACL (cross-section  area, length, and volume)(9,10,36)-Decreased collagen fiber density(36)-Tibial plateau differences(36)-Increased posterior-inferior  slope of the lateral tibial plateau-Femoral notch differences(9,10,36)-Narrower femoral notch width(9,10)-Taller femoral notch height(36)-Smaller femoral notch angle(36)-Increased hypermobility/joint laxity(10,36)-Hormonal influences, particularly estrogen levels(9,10,36)-Monthly hormonal changes may decrease ligament or muscle strength and place females at a greater risk of sustainingan ACL injury during the preovulatory phase of the menstrual cycle than during the postovulatory phase(10,36)-Elite female athletes with elevated serum relaxin concentrations may be at greater risk for ACL injury(36)-Cyclic variations in knee laxity are of sufficient magnitude in some women to substantially alter their knee jointbiomechanics(36)-Estrogen, testosterone, and relaxin receptors on the ACL and skeletal muscle suggest that these sex hormones have thepotential to directly influence these structures at the knee joint(36)-Biomechanical(9,10,13)-Neuromuscular imbalances (increased quadriceps activation and decreased hamstring activity during landings)(9)-Hamstring muscles are very important to stabilizing the knee joint during landing tasks. A lowerhamstring-to-quadriceps  ratio has been shown to contribute to an increase in genuvalgus and tibial rotation anglesduring dynamic movements, which increase loading of the ACL(38)-Girls (age 10–13  years, Tanner stage II) with decreased hamstring strength (~2x lower hamstring-to-quadriceps  ratio)have significantly greater valgus at the knee, reduced hip abduction, and greater ACL loading at the time of peakanteroposterior ground reaction forces when landing from a leap compared to girls with stronger hamstring strength,according to the results from an Australian study of 33 healthy girls(38)-Altered neuromuscular control in the lower extremity: Females demonstrated increased knee abduction and ankleeversion in a jumping maneuver in a study of 54 males and 72 females (all adolescents)(10)-Female athletes with limited sagittal plane motion during landing exhibit a biomechanical profile that may put them atgreater risk for ACL injury, according to a study in the United States (13)-The subjects were 58 female competitive soccer players (ages 11–20  years) with no history of knee pain-Subjects were grouped by their hip and knee flexion angles during the deceleration phase of drop-landing.Subjectswith decreased hip and knee flexion had increased knee valgus, increased knee adductor moments, and decreasedenergy absorption at the hip and knee as compared to subjects with increased hip and knee flexion Consequently,subjects with increased reliance on the knee extensor muscles on landing may be at greater risk of ACL injury-In a follow-up  study, the same authors foundthat an ACL injury prevention training program improved use of thehip extensor muscles on drop-landing,  thereby decreasing knee extensor moments and increasing energy absorptionat the hip(56)-Movement patterns (e.g., sudden deceleration, change of direction cutting movements, landing from a jump in kneehyperextension vs. flexion)(9,36)-ACL strain is related to maximal load and timing of ground reaction forces. A more erect posture is commonlyassociated with increased vertical ground reaction forces. Thus, a more upright posture when contacting the groundduring the early stages of deceleration tasks has been implicated in ACL injury(36)-Authors of a systematic review of studies published between 1982 and 2011 analyzed factors proposed to contribute tothe between-sex  disparity in noncontact ACL injuries from the onset of puberty(27)-Despite evidence confirming that estrogen receptors are located on the ACL, there remains conflicting evidence as tohow and whether estrogen affects the metabolic and mechanical properties of the ACL, particularly in pubescent girlswho have not yet begun menstruating-Unlike boys, girls do not undergo an accelerated increase in muscle strength during puberty, particularly evident inhamstring strength(27,38)-In addition to evidence that suggests girls display an increase in knee valgus alignment throughout puberty, theirhamstring muscle strength appears to lag behind that of their quadriceps strength. These two components combinedmay alter girls’ ability to stabilize the knee and protect the ACL during dynamic landing movements-More longitudinal studies are needed to examinelower limb musculoskeletal structural and functional changes (e.g.,strength, flexibility, knee joint laxity) experienced by girls throughout puberty and how these changes are related toestrogen fluctuations or how they affect girls’ ability to jump/land safely-In addition, studies need to be conducted to analyze the effects of puberty on the neuromuscular activation patterns orlower limb biomechanics when both boys and girls are performing sport-specific  movement patterns

Age–Incidence of ACL injuries increases at ≥ 11 years of age regardless of sex, with the highest prevalence of sports injuriesoccurring at the onset of and during puberty(9,14,27)–There is very little evidence of a sex difference in ACL injury rates in prepubescent athletes(14,27)–Early puberty may be a critical period related to increased ACL injury risk factors in females based on research analyzingknee abduction angles from 325 U.S. subjects during a drop vertical jump during puberty and then post puberty(14)-No sex differences in peak knee abduction angle or moment (valgus torque) during the drop vertical jump betweenpubertal males and females, but peak knee abduction angle increased between puberty and post puberty in females butnot in males-Period of rapid adolescent growth may a greater risk factor for ACL injury in female athletes than male athletes–Puberty is associated with rapid skeletal growth and hormonal rises, both of which are thought to contribute to alterationsin ACL metabolic and mechanical properties, as well as to changes in lower limb strength and flexibility(27,38)–Risk of ACL tear in children and adolescents with open growth plates is low, but participation in organized sportssignificantly increases the risk(9,15)-Authors of a retrospective analysis ofdata collected from health insurance companies on six million athletes in theUnited States found that 30.8% of all injuries in soccer players aged 5–18  years involved the knee and 6.7% were ACLtears(15)
Genetics: familial tendency has been identified(9,36)

Any initial pain? Difficulty weight bearing? -Child may report that the knee felt unstable, a sense of “giving way,” or that something shifted inside the knee(5,9) -When did the swelling start? How much swelling did the patient experience? Was there any redness or warmth to touch? -Rapid onset (within 47 hours) and persistence of a large effusion are associated with intraarticular pathology(6,9)  -47% of children aged 712  years with a hemarthrosis have an ACL injury(1)

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Did the patient undergo joint aspiration due to the presence of large effusion to alleviate pain and improve ROM?(9) Conservative treatment  may consist of bracing, physical therapy, activity modification, and patient education; however, conservative treatment has been found to be largely unsuccessful at preventing meniscal injury and early onset of degenerative changes.(2) Young athletes may have difficulty complying with activity restrictions, as noncompetitive recreational activities still involve contraindicated movements(48) Surgical intervention is now generally considered to be the standard of care. Less clearly defined is which surgical technique should be performed and what is the most optimal postoperative rehabilitation program. There is no consensus(31,32) The rationale for surgical intervention for ACL tears includes stabilizing the knee in order to prevent functional instability as well as reduce the risk of developing additional meniscal and articular cartilage injuries caused by ongoing abnormal joint forces(28) Orthopedic surgeons need to consider the patient’s physiologic age and potential for growth by reviewing the patient’s radiographs to determine bone age. Bone age must be determined when deciding on the operative procedure in order to minimize the risk of growth disruption.(48) Some surgeons will also consider the use of Tanner staging to classify the patient’s physiologic age(31) Three main reconstruction techniques(9) Bone-patella  tendon-bone  autograft Hamstring autograft Allograft tendon (cadaver) Three types of surgical procedures(16,31) Intraarticular, transphyseal, transosseous reconstruction Greatest risk of physeal injury and growth disturbance. Used for skeletally mature patients(31) Surgeon drills holes through both the proximal tibialphysis and distal femoral physis(32) Intraarticular, physeal-sparing,  transosseous reconstruction Spares the physis and provides a method to restore joint stability and maximally avoid the risk of growth disturbance(31) Combined intra-  and extraarticular, partial transphyseal, extraosseous stabilization Based on a 2010 systematic review of 13 case series evaluating ACL reconstruction techniques in skeletally immature patients with wide open physes, physealsparing  and transphyseal techniques are both associated with excellent clinical outcomes and low incidence of growth complications in Tanner stage II and III patients. Physealsparing  is also associated with excellent clinical outcomes in Tanner stage I patients(49)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? For acute ligamentous sprain, NSAIDs such as ibuprofen, naproxen, and indomethacin are often prescribed. Acetaminophen may also be prescribed. Narcotics, such as acetaminophenhydrocodone,  may be prescribed for severe pain per physician’s postoperative pain management(9)
diagnostic tests completed: X-rays  (AP, lateral, and tunnel views): May reveal injuries to the physes, tibial eminence avulsion fractures, osteochondral injuries, Segond fracture (small avulsion fracture of the lateral capsular tibial margin, often the middle third), proximal tibia or distal femur fracture, or loose bodies(1,9,31)
Segond fractures are often associated with the presence of an ACL injury and would indicate follow-up  with an MRI(31)
Radiographs can be used to calculate the patient’s bone age by analyzing the pattern of epiphyses and bone development of the hand and wrist(31)

MRI: MRI is considered the gold standard for diagnosing ligamentous injuries and intraarticular structures in adults.(5) It is able to detect associated bone bruise, if present.(9) MRI for the diagnosis of ACL injury in children is controversial.(4)
In a 10-year-old  child, complex joint effusions seen on MRI correlated highly with avulsion fractures (66% of hemarthroses and 100% of lipohemarthroses)(12)

In the skeletally immature, the overall MRI detection of ACL tears has been reported to have 95% sensitivity and 88% specificity rates compared with arthroscopy; however, other studies report sensitivity rates of 64% to 78% and specificity rates of 94% to 100%.The lower sensitivity rate was attributed to inexperience with assessment of pediatric/adolescent anatomy and the relatively higher rate of incomplete tears in this age group(31)
Belgian researchers reported no significant differences between the 1.5 and 3.0-T  sensitivity and specificity rates for diagnosing ACL and meniscal injuries(34)
Children have increased vascularity of the meniscus, which can cause enhancement within the midsubstance of the meniscus, mimicking an ACL tear(31)
Arthroscopy: Can be utilized if clinical exam is ambiguous. Typically, this test is not necessary to diagnose an ACL injury(2)

relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Anthropometric characteristics –Assess BMI and compare to age- and sex-matched  data –Evaluate leg lengths(17) –Growth plates -Distal femoral physis(32) -The most active growth plate in the human body, contributing to roughly 1cm of growth per year -It contributes to roughly 70% of the longitudinal growth of the femur and 37% of the overall growth in the lower limb -Proximal tibialphysis(32) -Contributes roughly 0.7 cm of growth per year -It contributes to roughly 55% of the longitudinal growth of the tibia and 25% of the overall growth of the lower limb
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess fit and safety of assistive devices. Assess ability to correctly don/doff knee brace
relevant tests and measures.balance: Balance –Perform single-leg  stance with eyes open and closed and note any asymmetry or compensations. It is important to note the presence of instability, trunk weakness, or gluteal muscle weakness, since the trunk and hip musculature play a significant role in hip and knee functional strength –The Pediatric Balance Scale (PBS) can be used
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess vascular status, noting distal pedal pulses. Assess for the presence of a DVT. Document heart rate (HR) and blood pressure (BP)Assess peripheral nerve involvement(5)Complete a functional assessment as indicated and note if the use of assistive devices is required
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Gait/locomotion –Assess gait; ensure compliance with any weight-bearing restrictions through use of assistive device and education. Note the presence of any gait asymmetry -Patients will present with an antalgic gait and decreased stance time on affected leg(8) –Assess patient’s ability to negotiate stairs safely, with/without adult supervision and the use of assistive devices –Assess running as appropriate Joint integrity and mobility –Laxity is normal in children, especially girls.(5) The clinician Use the uninjured knee as a baseline for comparison. A firm endpoint indicates the presence of an intact ACL.(7) An individual with physiological laxity will have increased anterior translation but will have a firm endpoint(7) –Assess patellar mobility and indicate any hyper-  or hypomobility present. Compare to uninvolved extremity –Assess joint laxity in other joints to gauge overall laxity(1) –Assess joint laxity in all planes. An ACL injury is often associated with damage to the collateral ligaments and menisci. A thorough assessment is necessary -ACL instabilityMost sensitive and highly specific diagnostic test for ACL injury, especially acute injury. Good negative predictive value(9) -Eighty-one  percent sensitivity and specificity with increasing values if the patient was examined under anesthesia(31) -There is a lack of research studies analyzing the Lachman test and other clinical examination procedures in pediatric and adolescent athletes(31)  -Position knee in 20–30°  of flexion. Stabilize the distal thigh with the upper hand. Place your other hand on the proximal tibia, with the thumb on the tibial tubercle and fingers on the calf. Translate the tibia forward on the femur(5) -Compare degree of anterior translation with uninvolved knee(9) -Lack of firm end feel indicates complete tear(9)Lower sensitivity but more specific for ACL tear than Lachman test, limiting its clinical utility. Favorable positive predictive value(18,31) -With the patient in the supine position, the examiner supports the ankle of the involved leg in one hand and the knee in the other hand. The leg is held in full extension. The examiner applies a valgus force at the knee while internally rotating the tibia, utilizing the hand that is supporting the ankle. The knee is then flexed to 40°. A positive test results in a ‘clunk’/knee subluxation at 20–30°  of flexion that will reduce further flexion at the knee(16) -Acutely, the pivot shift test will be difficult to assess due to muscle guarding. In a patient with chronic ACL deficiency, the deficiency will be easily detected(7)Low sensitivity (42%) for ACL integrity, particularly in the assessment of acute injuries, but may have greater diagnostic value in the presence of chronic ACL deficiency(9,31) –Collateral ligament instability -Valgus stress test(5) -Varus stress test(5) –PCL instability -Posterior drawer test(9) –Meniscal injury -Sixty-nine  percent of pediatric patients with ACL tears have been reported to have concurrent meniscal injuries. Such patients often present with joint effusion, snapping, or giving away as the mechanisms of injury(31) -Medial meniscal tears are often associated with chronic ACL tears, and lateral meniscal tears are more commonly associated with acute ACL injuries(28) -The most common tests for meniscal injuries, the McMurray test(2) and the Apley compression test,(2) have questionable clinical utility and limited evaluative information in the pediatric population. Reliance on these tools to detect or rule out meniscal injuries is imprudent; diagnostic accuracy has been reported as low as 29% to 59%(31)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Assess bilateral lower extremity muscle strength via manual muscle testing (MMT), as appropriate –Assess ability to perform a straight-leg  raise (SLR) without an extensor lag, which indicates function of quadriceps and patella tendon
observation inspection palpation includi: Palpate medial and lateral joint lines for meniscal tenderness
Palpate over the collateral ligaments and physes(5)
Palpate patella and note the presence of any abnormality(1)
Assess for swelling or joint effusion. Take circumferential measurements(5)
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Assess passive and active ROM at the hip, knee, and ankle –Restricted ankle, knee, or hip flexion can significantly alter the biomechanics for a proper “squat technique” –Patients will typically present with decreased knee extension(8) –Assess flexibility of entire lower extremity Self-care/activities  of daily living  (objective testing) –Assess functional mobility with assistive device, as appropriate per environment -Up/down stairs -Up/down curbs -Up/down ramps -Ambulate on level/uneven terrain  -Sit to/from stand -Shower/bathtub transfer -Car transfer
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess proprioception, kinesthesia, and light touch as indicated and compared to uninvolved lower extremity
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: See Joint integrity and mobility , above –Lower Extremity Functional Scale (LEFS) –Lysholm scale –International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC) score

contraindications precautions: Hypertension due to cold applications can acutely increase BP
Avoid aggressive treatment with cold modalities over an acute wound
Avoid placement over superficial nerves for extended periods (> 1 hour)
Cold may be counterproductive if being used to facilitate muscle relaxation and reduce pain in patients who do not tolerate the modality
Stimulation through or across the chest
Used in close proximity to diathermy treatment
Over an area of active bleeding
Implanted cardiac pacemaker or other implanted electronics
Active bone growth at the epiphysis

Depending on the child’s age, their ability to focus and attention span may be limited and it is extremely important to incorporate play activities with children in order to maximize their active participation and keep them motivated
other: Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies
Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for DVT

It is important to incorporate developmentally appropriate activities when engaging children and adolescents in treatment intervention. Therapists must be aware of physical, emotional, and cognitive stages of development when developing and implementing treatment sessions for children and adolescents

of ACL injuries in the skeletally immature patient(32) Physical therapy is recommended whether an athlete chooses nonsurgical or surgical intervention(9) –There is insufficient evidence regarding the prognosis: Prognosis –The prognosis depends on the severity of the ACL tear and concomitant injuries, such as meniscal tears or MCL strains. There appears to be a consensus in the literature that complete ACL tears that are treated conservatively have a poor outcome, with resulting knee instability, increasing risk of secondary meniscal injury and decreased function(9) -Most patients who are treated conservatively eventually decide to undergo ACL reconstruction; however, delaying surgical reconstruction for a torn ACL increases the risk of secondary meniscal injury(9,16) –Predictors of subsequent ACL or other knee injury despite undergoing ACL reconstruction and rehabilitation -Approximately 1 in 4 young athletes who undergo ACL reconstructive surgery sustain a second knee injury.(42) Documented incidence of ACL reinjury is varied but high, ranging from 6% to 27%, with the highest (24%) short-term (within 2 years postsurgery) second injury rate noted in younger, more active patients(11) -ACL injury is associated with early onset of knee osteoarthritis, regardless of surgical or nonsurgical treatment(9,47) -Swedish researchers analyzed data from the Swedish national ACL register (20,842 patients were included in the final analysis) to identify predictors for reinjury or contralateral ACL injury(45) -Patients included were those who underwent ACL reconstruction between January 2005 and February 2013. Graft type did not predict additional ACL reconstruction; however, only those who underwent hamstring tendon autografts were included for further regression analysis -Seven hundred two patients had revision and 591 underwent contralateral ACL reconstruction -Significant predictors of additional ACL reconstruction were age (a 4-fold  increased rate for those < 16 years of age vs. those > 35 years of age), time between injury and primary surgery (2- to 3-fold  increased rate for ACL reconstruction within 0–90  days vs. > 365 days), and playing soccer at the time of the primary ACL injury –Athletes who undergo ACL reconstructive surgery and subsequent rehabilitation are typically out of competitive play for roughly 6–9 months(9) -Wells et al. reviewed the course of 55 teenagers (40 girls, 15 boys), mean age 16 years, and reported that the average time from surgery to recovery of 85% of normal quadriceps strength was 5.42 months(15) -Fifty-nine  percent achieved 85% or better strength in < 6 months, with 50% returning to full activity in 6 months –ACL reconstruction in the skeletally immature patient has the risk of causing growth plate injury from tunnel placement or graft fixation and requires thoughtful consideration in the younger population with partial or complete ACL tears; however, there are very few published reports of growth plate arrest. Growth plate injury is avoidable with meticulous surgery(10,13,15)  -Authors of a 2010 systematic review found that the risk of growth disturbances was low; however,at that time no RCTshad compared different surgical techniques or compared surgical to nonsurgical intervention(13) -Femoral or tibial overgrowth is possible with stimulation of an active physis secondary to the operative procedure and this is not always predictable. Additionally, if a growth spurt occurs in close proximity to an ACL reconstruction, there is a potential too for asymmetric long-bone  growth, possibly justifying a delay in ACL reconstruction in some cases(13) -The majority of growth disturbances and angular deformities have been associated with graft fixation devices or bone plugs leading to bony bars across the lateral distal femoral physis, epiphysiodesis effects of fixation devices crossing the tibialphysis, and poorer tunnel placement and tunnel diameter(16) –Research suggests that secondary ACL injury risk is strongly related to multiplanar movement asymmetries of the lower extremities. Multidimensional kinematic data indicate that asymmetrical hip and knee movement patterns and force generation can result in compensatory strategies within both extremities that can also be present in the nonsurgical extremity(42) –Altered neuromuscular control of the hip and knee during dynamic landing and postural instability after ACL reconstructive surgery are predictors of a second ACL injury after an athlete returns to sport(43)

treatment summary: Treatment summary –Post-ACL  reconstructive rehabilitation protocols have evolved significantly over the past few decades. There has been a shift from more conservative efforts with prolonged immobilization and delayed strengthening to current guidelines that promote immediate, protected weight-bearing, early ROM and functional strengthening, and neuromuscular training.(42) The consensus is that a structured ACL physical therapy protocol should be followed with the goals of increasing strength, neuromuscular reeducation, endurance, agility, and coordination.(21) However, research is limited to guide a specific evidence-based  physical therapy treatment approach. There is no consensus on the type or number of exercises to include in the rehabilitation program. At this point, the research is focused on conservative management weighed against surgery, not what type of conservative management yields the best outcomes -Of 625 studies included in a systematic review, only 7 studies provided adequate comparisons between nonoperative and operative ACL groups -Best evidence available was level III, and therefore the authors concluded that data were inadequate to determine whether surgical intervention vs. nonsurgical intervention had better outcomes for skeletally immature children and adolescents with ACL injuries(13) -Authors of a2012 systematic review of treatment studies between 1966 and 2011 found methodological deficiencies that includedsmall numbers of patients in some studies, weak study design, inadequate description of rehabilitation protocols, and poor description of outcome criteria and assessments. Consequently, they recommended caution when interpreting reviews on pediatric ACL reconstruction rehabilitationpublished before 2012(40) –In general, postoperative care/rehabilitation progression for the skeletally immature athlete is similar to that for adults but with greater initial precautions and often a more conservative progression. This may be due to the uncertainty regarding the strength of the graft and the risk of growth disturbances, as well as the lack of evidence-based  practice guidelines(31,32) -The main differences between postoperative rehabilitation in skeletally immature patients as compared to adult patients are as follows: -Slower progression towards jumping and running to reduce the impact of loading on the physis -Less use of external loads -Primarily home-based  functional exercises -Later return to pivoting sports (after 9 to 12 months) -In addition, when implementing strength training for prepubescent athletes an emphasis should be placed on lighter resistance and increased repetitions while maintaining proper body alignment and technique with developmentally age-appropriate activities(21) –For acute ACL injury, it is generally recommended that the patient receive PRICEMM therapy: Protection, Relative Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation, Medications, Modalities(9) –Gait training should be completed in order to properly educate the patient and/or primary caregivers on the proper use of crutches for ambulation with any weight-bearing restrictions, transfer training, and stair negotiation(9)  –Conservative treatment may be an option for carefully selected, highly compliant patients with low physical demands and no other pathologies(16) –Research is limited on rehabilitation after ACL avulsion fractures. It is suggested that postoperative rehabilitation guidelines mimic those for bone-patellar  tendon-bone  ACL reconstruction because both procedures require bony union before significant stress can be placed on the attachment site(12) –General goals for nonoperative treatment intervention in patients with ACL tears are to increase lower extremity strength, restore full ROM, restore functional activity, restore normal gait biomechanics, and improve joint proprioception with closed-chain  exercises. Such treatment intervention allows for quadriceps-hamstring  co-contraction while minimizing ACL strain and patellofemoral joint reaction forces, protecting the secondary structures of the knee(22) Attempt to return to activity is typically advised 6 months after surgery, but functional performance deficits and gait abnormalities are often still evident and can have important implications for future function. maintenance or prevention: Rehabilitation programs need to emphasize core and symmetrical bilateral lower extremity neuromuscular control to minimize the risk of reinjury prior to RTS clearance. Asymmetry in biomechanical neuromuscular control with tasks such as jumping, landing, and cutting can increase the risk of future injury to the same knee or even the other knee(11,43) U.S. researchers conducted a nonrandomized controlled study involving 98 participants: 56 subjects had undergone unilateral ACL reconstruction and had been released to RTS and 42 were uninjured, activity-matched  peers (29 females and 13 males). Subjects were asked to perform a bilateral drop vertical jump maneuver from a 31cm box(11) –Subjects who had ACL reconstruction were unable to equally distribute force between the involved and uninvolved lower extremity during a bilateral landing task. There was no difference between male and female athletes in peak vertical ground landing force. The athletes continued to favor the uninvolved limb despite clearance to RTS –Despite completing an ACL rehabilitation program and being cleared for full return to level I and level II sports, these subjects continued to favor the uninvolved limb with asymmetries in peak vertical ground reaction force during landing from a bipedal task compared to the control group

ACL prevention programs There is a need for additional research in order to develop evidence-based  training programs designed for teaching youth, especially girls, safe and proper landing techniques in an attempt to reduce the incidence of noncontact ACL injuries.(27) There is a void in the literature to validate whether or not prepubescent children respond the same as postpubescent children to ACL programs; however, children as young as 10 years of age demonstrate at-risk movement patterns associated with ACL injury and may benefit from these ACL prevention programs. Late childhood is a critical period for refining movement skills and an ideal time to intervene to reduce the risk of ACL injury(27,37) –Strength training has been proven safe and effective as long as direct supervision is provided and age-appropriate guidelines are followed.(37) Strength training can be safely started in prepubescent athletes as early as age 7 years if designed appropriately with an emphasis on lighter resistance, increased repetitions, proper technique , and coordination. It is important to note that children mature at varying rates and strength training programs must be individualized(21) –Skeletally immature children are prone to overuse injuries; it is very important to gradually increase resistance while increasing flexibility, strength, and motor skills according to age-appropriate  guidelines.(37) Exercises should always be performed in a pain-free  range(21) –Neuromuscular strength training programs should be incorporated into the warm-up  period of training sessions for young athletes in order to reduce the risk of ACL and other knee injuries. This will promote team and player compliance in order to maximize the benefit of the prevention program(44) –Strength training should emphasize gluteus maximus and medius in order to improve dynamic hip abduction and femoral rotation to prevent valgus collapse at the knee(37)  -Gluteus maximus and medius weakness has been identified as a predictor of ACL injury secondary to the inability of the weak muscles to keep the hip abducted during high single-leg  activities such as landing and cutting(37) -Progress exercises from double limb to single-limb once proper form is repeatedly demonstrated -Specific exercises to isolate gluteus medius and maximus: side-lying  hop abduction, side planks, lateral band walk, single-limb  squat, single-leg dead lifts(37) -Emphasize hamstring strengthening in order to assist with preventing dynamic knee valgus and tibial rotation. Examples of eccentric hamstring strengthening exercises are partnered Russian hamstring curls, agility training with unanticipated change of direction, jump landing with emphasis on proper hip, trunk, and knee alignment -Core stability training, proprioceptive training, perturbations, and postural sway corrections should be included in multifaceted strength training(37) -It is important to note that if there is an apparent leg dominance, strengthening each leg in isolation should be emphasized(37) Authors of a 2012 systematic review and meta-analysis  of studies evaluating ACL injury prevention programs found a significant reduction in ACL injuries after a preventive training program(33) –Thirteen studies met the criteria –A greater duration of balance training was associated with a higher risk for ACL injury, while a greater time spent on static stretching was associated with a lower risk for noncontact ACL injuries –Neuromuscular training with proprioceptive, plyometric, and strength exercises may reduce ACL injuries in female athletes(9,36) Sport-specific  training programs incorporating strength, balance, and stability exercises may be beneficial for reducing ACL injury rates in adolescent female soccer players(30) –Authors of a 2009 randomized controlled study in Sweden analyzed the effects of a sports injury prevention program for 230 female soccer clubs, with players ranging from 12 to 17 years of age –There were 2,479 players in the intervention group and 2,085 players in the control group, making this study the largest sports injury prevention study at the time it was published –The intervention group completed a 15-minute  neuromuscular warm-up  program that was intended to replace the conventional warm-up.  The warm-up  included six knee control and core stability exercises: one-legged  and two-legged knee squats, pelvic lifts, bench step-up,  lunges, and jump/landings. Each exercise increased in difficulty –Coaches were instructed to carry out the program twice a week –During the season, there were 96 acute knee injuries, 21 of which were ACL injuries. don’t go into a “knock-kneed” position; bend your knees and hips closer to 90° when landing from a jump; land evenly on two feet, with a toe to heel landing; try to land softly, not stiffly –Immediately following completion of the jumps, each IG athlete watched video clips of her own spike jump landings in full speed and slow motion, stopping at relevant frames that illustrated where the athlete could improve on her jump-landing  performance –IG athletes were allowed to ask questions to clarify jump-landing  techniques during the augmented feedback, which averaged 3–4 minutes/athlete –After the augmented feedback session, the IG repeated five spike jumps while being videotaped –Filming of five volleyball spikes for each athlete in both groups occurred at 2 and 4 weeks post initial videotape session –There were no differences in landing biomechanics between groups at baseline  –At week 4, statistical differences in maximal hip flexion (~30°) and trunk flexion (15°) were greater in the IG.
